Literature Review¶

[Mal87] (p. 1) defines market efficient formally:

‘the market is said to be efficient with respect to some information set, , if security prices would be unaffected by revealing that information to all participants. Moreover, efficiency with respect to an information set, , implies that it is impossible to make economic profits by trading on the basis of ’

The three classical categories for the information set, as posed by [Fam70] are: weak form, where is past prices; semi-strong form, where is all publicly available information (including past prices); strong form, where is all information, including private (and all publicly available information).

One can ask if hypothetical trading based on a specific would earn economic profits as a test for market efficiency related to . Nevertheless, this requires a specific model that ‘specifies the nature of market equilibrium when prices ‘fully reflect’ available information’ [Fam70] (p. 414).

As [FAM91] (p. 1575), referring to [Fam70], states ‘market efficiency per se is not testable’. Anomalous evidence can refer to efficiency or the asset pricing modeling, the split being ambiguous in accordance with [Rol77].

In this approach, one must first choose , then specify a model of ‘normal’ returns, and finally compute the abnormal returns as the difference between the return on a security and its normal return, using ([CLM97]). ‘If the abnormal security return in unforecastable, […] then the hypothesis of market efficiency is not rejected’ [CLM97] (p. 22).

[Fam70] concludes weak-form tests are strongly in support of the market efficiency hypothesis, and semi-strong form tests also support the hypothesis. Two decades later, [FAM91] concludes controversy about market efficiency lies mostly on return predictability tests.

In the case of efficiency related to political events, [LB06] find markets react to political uncertainty related to elections. Similar findings are reported in [GV13] and [Sma15]. [MBMP16] concludes markets under-react to elections. [MdS16] analyses the impact of political events on the main stock market index in Brazil and concludes only major events impact the index.
